canonical_explanation.text: Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring, ensuring the continuity of species. It is broadly classified into asexual and sexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction involves a single parent and produces genetically identical offspring (clones). Common modes include binary fission (Amoeba, bacteria), sporulation (Penicillium, mosses), budding (yeast, Hydra), fragmentation (Spirogyra, Planaria), and vegetative propagation in plants (runners, rhizomes, tubers). Organisms like Bryophyllum reproduce via adventitious buds on leaves. Sexual reproduction involves the formation and fusion of male and female gametes (syngamy), producing genetically diverse offspring. The three phases of sexual reproduction are pre-fertilisation (gametogenesis and gamete transfer), fertilisation (fusion of gametes to form a zygote), and post-fertilisation (zygote development into an embryo). Organisms may be unisexual (dioecious) having separate sexes, or bisexual (monoecious/hermaphrodite) possessing both male and female reproductive organs. Every organism has a definite life span, from a few days (mayfly) to thousands of years (banyan tree). Some organisms show both asexual and sexual reproduction depending on conditions. The life cycle of an organism includes juvenile, reproductive, and senescent phases. Meiosis is essential in sexual reproduction as it halves the chromosome number, which is restored upon fertilisation, maintaining chromosome constancy across generations.
rules: Asexual reproduction produces genetically identical offspring (clones) from a single parent
Binary fission: parent body divides into two equal halves (e.g., Amoeba, Paramecium, bacteria)
Budding: a bud develops as an outgrowth and separates to form a new organism (e.g., yeast, Hydra)
Sporulation: spores are asexual reproductive units that germinate under favourable conditions (e.g., Penicillium, Rhizopus)
Fragmentation: parent body breaks into fragments, each growing into a new organism (e.g., Spirogyra, Planaria)
Vegetative propagation uses vegetative parts like runners, tubers, rhizomes, suckers for plant reproduction
Sexual reproduction involves formation and fusion of gametes (syngamy) leading to genetic variation
Gametes are haploid (n) and their fusion forms a diploid zygote (2n)
Organisms can be unisexual (dioecious) or bisexual (monoecious/hermaphrodite)
Life span of organisms varies widely: mayfly (1-2 days) to banyan tree (hundreds of years)
Meiosis during gametogenesis halves chromosome number, maintaining constancy across generations
Post-fertilisation events include zygote development into embryo (embryogenesis)

questions.question_text: Binary fission in Amoeba is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Binary fission in Amoeba is a form of asexual reproduction where the parent cell divides into two equal daughter cells. It involves a single parent and produces genetically identical offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction requires fusion of gametes from two parents. Vegetative propagation is specific to plants. Parthenogenesis is development of an egg without fertilisation. Binary fission is a simple asexual method involving cell division.

questions.question_text: Which organism reproduces by budding?
questions.explanation_correct: Yeast reproduces asexually by budding. A small bud-like outgrowth develops on the parent cell, gradually enlarges, and eventually separates to form a new individual.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba reproduces by binary fission. Planaria reproduces by regeneration/fragmentation. Spirogyra reproduces by fragmentation. Budding is characteristic of yeast and Hydra.

questions.question_text: Vegetative propagation in Bryophyllum occurs through:
questions.explanation_correct: Bryophyllum reproduces vegetatively through adventitious buds that arise from the notches of its leaves. These buds develop into small plantlets that fall off and grow into new plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stem cuttings are used in plants like rose and sugarcane. Root tubers are found in sweet potato. Runners are seen in strawberry and lawn grass. Bryophyllum specifically uses leaf buds.

questions.question_text: An organism reproduces by breaking into two or more fragments, each of which grows into a complete organism. This mode of asexual reproduction is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Fragmentation is the mode of asexual reproduction where the body of the organism breaks into two or more fragments, each of which can regenerate into a complete organism. Examples include Spirogyra and Planaria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Budding involves outgrowth formation on the parent body. Binary fission divides the parent into two equal halves. Sporulation involves formation and dispersal of spores. Fragmentation is the breaking of the body into pieces.

questions.question_text: Conidia are asexual reproductive structures formed in:
questions.explanation_correct: Conidia are asexual spores produced exogenously on specialised hyphae called conidiophores in fungi like Penicillium. They are dispersed by wind and germinate to form new organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydra reproduces by budding. Amoeba reproduces by binary fission. Bryophyllum uses adventitious buds. Conidia are specific to certain fungi like Penicillium and Aspergillus.

questions.question_text: A farmer propagates sugarcane by planting stem pieces in the field. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Planting stem cuttings of sugarcane is an example of vegetative propagation, a type of asexual reproduction in plants. The stem pieces develop roots and shoots to grow into new plants genetically identical to the parent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction involves gamete fusion. Sporulation involves spore formation. Parthenogenesis is development from unfertilised eggs. Using stem cuttings is a standard vegetative propagation method.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reproduces by binary fission?
questions.explanation_correct: Paramecium reproduces asexually by binary fission. The cell divides transversely into two equal daughter cells. Both Amoeba and Paramecium are classic examples of binary fission.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yeast reproduces by budding. Hydra reproduces by budding. Penicillium reproduces by sporulation (conidia). Paramecium divides by transverse binary fission.

questions.question_text: Potato tubers, ginger rhizomes, and onion bulbs are all examples of:

options.text: Structures that require pollination to develop

questions.explanation_correct: Potato tubers, ginger rhizomes, and onion bulbs are all vegetative propagules. They are modified stems that serve as units of asexual (vegetative) reproduction, producing new plants identical to the parent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These are modified stems, not roots. They do not arise from sexual reproduction or require pollination. They are vegetative propagules used in asexual reproduction.

questions.question_text: Zoospores produced by aquatic fungi such as Chlamydomonas are:

options.text: Motile asexual reproductive structures with flagella
Haploid gametes that fuse during syngamy

questions.explanation_correct: Zoospores are motile asexual reproductive structures that possess flagella for locomotion. They are formed in aquatic organisms like Chlamydomonas and certain fungi, and they germinate into new organisms without gamete fusion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zoospores are motile, not non-motile. They are asexual structures, not formed after fertilisation or gametes. They are haploid structures used for asexual reproduction, distinguished by their flagella.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a method of vegetative propagation in plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Conidia are asexual spores produced by fungi like Penicillium, not a method of vegetative propagation in plants. Runners, eyes of potato, and rhizomes are all examples of vegetative propagation in flowering plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Runners (strawberry), eyes of potato tuber, and rhizomes (ginger) are all genuine vegetative propagation methods in plants. Conidia are fungal spores and belong to sporulation, not vegetative propagation.

questions.question_text: Offspring produced through asexual reproduction are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Offspring produced through asexual reproduction are genetically identical to the parent and to each other, and are therefore called clones. Since only one parent is involved and no meiosis or gamete fusion occurs, there is no genetic variation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hybrids result from crosses between genetically different parents. Variants show genetic differences. Mutants carry mutations. Clones are genetically identical copies produced by asexual reproduction.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Asexual reproduction is common in organisms with simple organisation.
Reason: Asexual reproduction does not involve meiosis or gamete formation.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Asexual reproduction is indeed common in simpler organisms, and it does not involve meiosis or gamete formation. However, the reason for asexual reproduction being common in simple organisms is their simple body organisation and ability to regenerate, not the absence of meiosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are independently correct. Asexual reproduction is common in simple organisms, and it does not involve meiosis. However, the reason does not correctly explain why simpler organisms favour asexual reproduction.

questions.question_text: Water hyacinth (Eichhornia) has become an invasive species in many water bodies primarily because:

options.text: It reproduces sexually at a very high rate
It reproduces vegetatively at a very fast rate through offsets
Its seeds are dispersed rapidly by wind
It undergoes sporulation in aquatic environments

questions.explanation_correct: Water hyacinth (Eichhornia) is called the 'Terror of Bengal' because it reproduces vegetatively at an extremely fast rate through offsets. This rapid vegetative propagation allows it to quickly cover entire water bodies, making it highly invasive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Its invasiveness is due to vegetative reproduction, not sexual reproduction, wind-dispersed seeds, or sporulation. The offsets allow rapid clonal multiplication in water bodies.

questions.question_text: Internal buds called gemmules are asexual reproductive structures found in:
questions.explanation_correct: Gemmules are internal buds found in sponges (Porifera). They are clusters of cells enclosed in a resistant shell and serve as asexual reproductive structures that survive unfavourable conditions and develop into new sponges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydra reproduces by external budding. Planaria by regeneration/fragmentation. Yeast by budding. Gemmules are unique to sponges and help them survive harsh environmental conditions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs is CORRECTLY matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Planaria reproduces asexually by fragmentation (and regeneration). The body breaks into fragments, and each fragment regenerates into a complete organism. This is a correct pairing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Penicillium reproduces by sporulation (conidia), not binary fission. Spirogyra reproduces by fragmentation, not budding. Amoeba reproduces by binary fission, not sporulation. Only Planaria-fragmentation is correct.

questions.question_text: A gardener wants to grow plants that are genetically identical to the parent plant. Which method should be preferred?

options.text: Growing plants from seeds obtained by cross-pollination
Growing plants from seeds obtained by self-pollination
Growing plants from seeds produced by open pollination

questions.explanation_correct: Vegetative propagation using stem cuttings produces genetically identical offspring (clones) because it involves only mitotic divisions from somatic cells of the parent plant. Seeds from any form of pollination involve meiosis and thus introduce genetic variation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination, self-pollination, and open pollination all involve sexual reproduction, which introduces genetic variation through meiosis and recombination. Only vegetative propagation ensures genetic identity with the parent.

questions.question_text: Multiple fission is a type of asexual reproduction seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Multiple fission occurs in Plasmodium (malarial parasite), where the parent cell divides into many daughter cells simultaneously. This produces numerous individuals at once, unlike binary fission which produces only two.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydra reproduces by budding. Yeast also reproduces by budding. Penicillium by sporulation (conidia). Multiple fission, producing many daughter cells at once, is characteristic of Plasmodium.

questions.question_text: Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of two gametes (male and female) in a process called syngamy or fertilisation. The male gamete fuses with the female gamete to form a diploid zygote.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Somatic cells and vegetative cells are not involved in sexual reproduction. Spores are asexual reproductive units. The defining feature of sexual reproduction is the fusion of two specialised sex cells (gametes).

questions.question_text: The process of fusion of male and female gametes is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Syngamy (or fertilisation) is the process of fusion of the male gamete with the female gamete to form a diploid zygote. It is the central event in sexual reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametogenesis is the formation of gametes. Embryogenesis is the development of embryo from the zygote. Parthenogenesis is development of an organism from an unfertilised egg. Syngamy specifically means gamete fusion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a significant advantage of sexual reproduction over asexual reproduction?

options.text: It is faster and requires less energy
It generates genetic variation in the offspring
It does not require a mate

questions.explanation_correct: The most significant advantage of sexual reproduction is that it generates genetic variation among offspring through meiosis and the random fusion of gametes. This variation helps populations adapt to changing environments and enhances survival.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction is generally slower and requires more energy than asexual reproduction. It does not always produce more offspring. It typically requires a mate (or at least gamete production). Genetic variation is its key advantage.

questions.question_text: An organism that possesses both male and female reproductive organs is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An organism possessing both male and female reproductive organs is called bisexual or hermaphrodite (also called monoecious in plants). Examples include earthworm, leech, tapeworm, and many flowering plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unisexual and dioecious organisms have separate sexes (male or female only). Asexual refers to reproduction without gametes. Bisexual/hermaphrodite correctly describes organisms with both types of reproductive organs.

questions.question_text: In external fertilisation, as seen in frogs and bony fishes, a large number of gametes are released because:

options.text: Gametes are very large in size
There is a high chance of gamete wastage in the aquatic environment

questions.explanation_correct: In external fertilisation, gametes are released into the external medium (water), where many are lost due to predation, water currents, and desiccation. To compensate for this high gamete wastage, organisms release a very large number of eggs and sperm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametes in external fertilisation are typically small, not large. Fertilisation occurs outside the body, not inside. Offspring do not need more genetic material. The large number compensates for gamete loss in the environment.

questions.question_text: Isogametes are gametes that:

options.text: Are morphologically different from each other

questions.explanation_correct: Isogametes (or homogametes) are gametes that are morphologically similar in size and appearance, making it difficult to distinguish male from female gametes. This condition is called isogamy and is seen in some algae like Cladophora.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Morphologically different gametes are called heterogametes (anisogametes). Isogametes are found in lower organisms, not only animals. They do fuse during fertilisation. Isogametes are defined by their morphological similarity.

questions.question_text: The cell division that occurs during gametogenesis to produce haploid gametes from diploid cells is:
questions.explanation_correct: Meiosis is the reductional division that occurs during gametogenesis. It reduces the diploid (2n) chromosome number of the parent cell to haploid (n) in the gametes, which is essential for maintaining chromosome constancy across generations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitosis produces diploid cells identical to the parent. Amitosis is direct cell division without spindle formation. Endomitosis involves chromosome duplication without cell division. Only meiosis produces haploid gametes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a pre-fertilisation event in sexual reproduction?

options.text: Cell differentiation to form gamete-producing organs

questions.explanation_correct: Embryogenesis (development of the embryo from the zygote) is a post-fertilisation event, not a pre-fertilisation event. Pre-fertilisation events include gametogenesis, gamete transfer, and development of reproductive organs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametogenesis (gamete formation), gamete transfer, and development of gamete-producing organs are all pre-fertilisation events. Embryogenesis occurs after fertilisation, making it a post-fertilisation event.

questions.question_text: The terms monoecious and dioecious are used for:

options.text: Plants, referring to presence of male and female flowers

questions.explanation_correct: The terms monoecious and dioecious are used for plants. A monoecious plant bears both male and female flowers on the same plant (e.g., maize, cucurbits), while a dioecious plant has male and female flowers on separate plants (e.g., papaya, date palm).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In animals, the equivalent terms are hermaphrodite and unisexual. These terms are specifically botanical. Fungi and bacteria have different terminology for their sexual states.

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the zygote undergoes development to form an embryo. This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Embryogenesis is the process of development of the embryo from the zygote. It involves cell division (mitosis), cell differentiation, and morphogenesis, leading to the formation of a multicellular organism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametogenesis is formation of gametes. Syngamy is fusion of gametes. Parturition is the process of childbirth. Embryogenesis specifically refers to embryo development from the zygote.

questions.question_text: In which type of fertilisation is there a greater chance of survival of the offspring and why?

options.text: External fertilisation, because more gametes are produced
Internal fertilisation, because it provides better protection to the developing embryo
External fertilisation, because it occurs in water
Internal fertilisation, because more gametes are produced

questions.explanation_correct: Internal fertilisation provides better chances of offspring survival because the embryo develops within the mother's body (or in protective structures like eggs), receiving nourishment and protection from predators and environmental hazards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although external fertilisation produces more gametes, this compensates for high mortality rather than ensuring survival. Internal fertilisation, despite fewer gametes, provides greater protection to embryos, leading to higher survival rates.

questions.question_text: Parthenogenesis is a special type of reproduction in which:

options.text: Two gametes of the same type fuse
A female gamete develops into a new organism without fertilisation
Vegetative parts give rise to new plants

questions.explanation_correct: Parthenogenesis is the development of a new organism from an unfertilised female gamete (egg) without the involvement of a male gamete. It is seen in organisms like honeybees (drone formation), rotifers, and some lizards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fusion of same-type gametes would be isogamy. Vegetative reproduction involves plant parts. Binary fission is a form of asexual reproduction. Parthenogenesis specifically involves development from an unfertilised egg.

questions.question_text: Organisms that produce both male and female gametes are referred to as:
questions.explanation_correct: Organisms that produce both male and female gametes are called homothallic or monoecious (in plants) and bisexual or hermaphrodite (in animals). The term homothallic is often used for fungi and lower organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dioecious and unisexual refer to organisms with only one type of sex organ. Heterothallic organisms require two different mating types. Homothallic/monoecious refers to organisms producing both types of gametes.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: In sexually reproducing organisms, the chromosome number remains constant from generation to generation.
Reason: Meiosis during gametogenesis halves the chromosome number, which is restored by fertilisation.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Meiosis produces haploid (n) gametes from diploid (2n) cells. When two gametes fuse during fertilisation, the diploid number is restored. This ensures chromosome number constancy across generations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true because chromosome number stays constant across generations in sexually reproducing organisms. The reason correctly explains why: meiosis halves and fertilisation restores the chromosome number.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms shows both asexual and sexual modes of reproduction?
questions.explanation_correct: Hydra can reproduce both asexually (by budding under favourable conditions) and sexually (under unfavourable conditions such as cold weather). This dual mode of reproduction is an adaptive strategy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba primarily uses binary fission. Elephants reproduce only sexually. Bacteria primarily use binary fission (though they have conjugation for gene transfer). Hydra is the correct answer as it clearly uses both modes.

questions.question_text: The zygote formed after fertilisation is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The zygote is always diploid (2n) because it is formed by the fusion of a haploid (n) male gamete and a haploid (n) female gamete. The fusion restores the diploid chromosome number characteristic of the species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haploid is the ploidy of gametes, not the zygote. Triploid and polyploid are unusual ploidy levels not typical of normal zygote formation. The zygote is diploid due to the combination of two haploid gametes.

questions.question_text: The life span of an organism refers to:

options.text: The period from birth to reproductive maturity only
The total time period an organism is expected to live
The period during which an organism can reproduce
The time taken for one cell cycle

questions.explanation_correct: Life span is defined as the total time period from birth to natural death during which an organism is expected to live. It varies greatly among organisms, from a few hours in some insects to thousands of years in certain trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reproductive period is only a part of the life span. The cell cycle duration is unrelated to life span. Life span encompasses the entire duration from birth to death, including juvenile, reproductive, and senescent phases.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms has the shortest life span?
questions.explanation_correct: Mayfly (Ephemera) has the shortest life span among the given options, living for only about 1-2 days as an adult. Tortoise can live over 100 years, banyan tree for hundreds of years, and parrot for several decades.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tortoise has a very long life span (100+ years). Banyan tree can live for hundreds or thousands of years. Parrot lives for several decades. Mayfly has one of the shortest life spans in the animal kingdom.

questions.question_text: The juvenile phase in an organism's life cycle is characterised by:

options.text: Growth and maturation before reaching reproductive age

questions.explanation_correct: The juvenile phase (also called vegetative phase in plants) is the period of growth and maturation before the organism attains reproductive maturity. During this phase, the organism grows in size and develops but cannot reproduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active reproduction occurs during the reproductive phase. Decline in metabolic activities and death occur during the senescent phase. The juvenile phase is specifically about growth before reproductive maturity.

questions.question_text: In plants, the juvenile phase is also known as the:
questions.explanation_correct: In plants, the juvenile phase is called the vegetative phase. During this phase, the plant grows by producing leaves, stems, and roots but does not produce flowers or fruits. It must attain maturity before entering the reproductive phase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reproductive phase involves flowering and fruiting. Senescent phase involves aging and death. Dormant phase is a period of inactivity. The vegetative phase is the plant-specific term for the juvenile phase.

questions.question_text: Some plants like bamboo flower only once in their lifetime and then die. Such plants are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Monocarpic plants (e.g., bamboo, Agave) flower and fruit only once in their lifetime and then die. The term 'mono' (one) + 'carpic' (fruit) indicates a single reproductive event. Bamboo species may take 50-100 years to flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polycarpic plants flower and fruit multiple times during their lifetime. Perennial plants live for more than two years. Deciduous refers to plants that shed leaves seasonally. Monocarpic correctly describes once-flowering plants.

questions.question_text: The senescent phase of an organism's life cycle is marked by:

options.text: Slowing of metabolism and progressive deterioration

questions.explanation_correct: The senescent phase is the old age phase characterised by a progressive decline in metabolic activities, deterioration of body functions, and eventually leading to death. Cells lose their ability to divide and repair efficiently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rapid growth occurs in the juvenile phase. Maximum reproductive capacity occurs in the reproductive phase. Active mitosis is characteristic of growing tissues. Senescence involves functional decline.

questions.question_text: Annual plants complete their life cycle in:
questions.explanation_correct: Annual plants complete their entire life cycle (from germination to seed production and death) within one growing season or one year. Examples include wheat, rice, and marigold. They germinate, grow, reproduce, and die within this period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants that take more than two years are perennials. Those completing their cycle in two years are biennials. Annual plants have the shortest life cycle among these categories, completing it within one season.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about life span is INCORRECT?

options.text: Life span is not correlated with the size of the organism
Every organism eventually dies except single-celled organisms which are considered immortal
Life span of organisms is always directly proportional to their body size
Some trees can live for thousands of years

questions.explanation_correct: It is incorrect to say that life span is always directly proportional to body size. A crow and a parrot are similar in size but have very different life spans. A large cow lives shorter than a small tortoise. Life span depends on genetics and species, not just body size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct as life span is not directly correlated with body size. Option B is partially correct regarding single-celled organisms. Option D is correct as trees like bristlecone pine live thousands of years. Option C is the incorrect statement.

questions.question_text: Biennial plants differ from annual plants in that they:

options.text: Complete their life cycle in two growing seasons
Live for more than ten years

questions.explanation_correct: Biennial plants complete their life cycle in two growing seasons. In the first year, they typically produce vegetative growth (leaves, stems, roots), and in the second year, they flower, produce seeds, and die. Examples include carrot and radish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biennial plants do reproduce sexually and produce seeds. They do not live for more than ten years. The defining feature is their two-year life cycle, contrasting with the single-year cycle of annuals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms has one of the longest life spans?
questions.explanation_correct: Among the given options, the tortoise has the longest life span, living for over 100-150 years. Some species like the Galapagos giant tortoise can live for over 175 years. Fruit flies live for about 30 days, butterflies for a few weeks, and rats for 3-4 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fruit fly has a very short life span (about 30 days). Butterflies live for a few weeks to months. Rats live for 3-4 years. Tortoise is well known for its exceptionally long life span.

questions.question_text: A student observed that a particular organism switches from asexual to sexual reproduction when environmental conditions become unfavourable. Which of the following best explains this strategy?

options.text: Sexual reproduction is faster than asexual reproduction
Sexual reproduction produces genetic variation, increasing chances of survival in changed conditions
Asexual reproduction cannot occur in unfavourable conditions

questions.explanation_correct: When conditions become unfavourable, organisms like Hydra switch to sexual reproduction because it generates genetic variation through meiosis and gamete fusion. This variation increases the probability that some offspring will be adapted to the changed environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction is slower and requires more resources. Asexual reproduction can occur in unfavourable conditions in some organisms. The key advantage of switching to sexual mode is the genetic variation it creates.

questions.question_text: Perennial plants are characterised by:

options.text: Completing their life cycle in one growing season
Dying after producing flowers and seeds once
Living for more than two years and reproducing repeatedly
Producing seeds only through asexual reproduction

questions.explanation_correct: Perennial plants live for more than two years and typically reproduce (flower and produce seeds) multiple times during their life span. Examples include mango, neem, and apple trees. They are also called polycarpic plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants completing the cycle in one season are annuals. Plants that die after one reproduction are monocarpic. Seeds are produced through sexual reproduction. Perennials are long-lived and reproduce multiple times.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly arranges organisms in INCREASING order of their life span?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct increasing order of life span is: Butterfly (few weeks) < Crow (about 15 years) < Tortoise (100-150 years) < Banyan tree (hundreds to thousands of years). This shows that life span varies greatly across different types of organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other arrangements incorrectly place organisms. Butterfly has the shortest life span, followed by crow, then tortoise, and banyan tree has the longest life span among the given options.

questions.question_text: The reproductive phase in human females starts at:
questions.explanation_correct: The reproductive phase in human females begins at puberty, typically between 10-14 years of age. This is marked by the onset of menstruation (menarche) and the maturation of reproductive organs under hormonal influence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reproductive organs are not mature at birth. 20 years is past the onset of puberty. Menopause marks the end, not the beginning, of the reproductive phase. Puberty is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Single-celled organisms like Amoeba are sometimes described as 'immortal' because:

options.text: They never die under any circumstances
They do not undergo natural death as the parent cell divides into daughter cells
They have an infinite life span
They can survive in all environmental conditions

questions.explanation_correct: Single-celled organisms like Amoeba are considered 'immortal' because they reproduce by binary fission where the parent cell divides into two daughter cells. There is no natural death in the conventional sense as the parent body continues in the form of its daughter cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They can die from environmental factors. They do not have truly infinite life spans. They cannot survive all conditions. The concept of 'immortality' here refers to the absence of a natural death event since the parent becomes the offspring.

questions.question_text: In higher plants, the transition from juvenile phase to reproductive phase can be identified by:
questions.explanation_correct: In higher plants, the transition from the vegetative (juvenile) phase to the reproductive phase is clearly marked by the appearance of flowers. Flowering indicates that the plant has attained reproductive maturity and is ready for sexual reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increased root growth occurs during vegetative phase. Leaf shedding is related to deciduousness. Reduced photosynthesis relates to senescence. Flowering is the definitive marker of entering the reproductive phase.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding reproduction and life span?

options.text: All organisms that reproduce sexually have longer life spans than those reproducing asexually
No organism can reproduce both sexually and asexually
Reproduction is essential for the survival of the species, not for the survival of the individual
Life span is always proportional to the number of offspring produced

questions.explanation_correct: Reproduction is a biological process that is essential for the continuity and survival of a species, not for the survival of an individual organism. An individual can live its entire life without reproducing, but the species would become extinct without reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many sexually reproducing organisms have short life spans. Many organisms (like Hydra, yeast) reproduce both sexually and asexually. Life span is not proportional to offspring number. Reproduction serves species survival, not individual survival.
